and Rail Roads-from which beg you 10 extract
such parts as will tend to give to our fellow citi-
zens, all the requisite information to enable them TO
Judge for themselves in relation to these very I'm
portant means of communication, that promise such
great advantages not only to the Iowrs, but more
particularly to our interior Country.


1t is scarcely conceivable how the members OF
the Franklin Institute, could be the advocates OF
Canals-and should endeavor TO encourage the en-
ormous expenses that the State of Pennsylvania is
about to incur, in prosecuting her Canal system
when there is so much reason to believe that the
whole will be superseded by the Rail Road System,
within shorter period than it wall be possible to
execute their Canal-at the same time.that they
had all this information within their reach.


What is stated in the Pamphlet sent you will
fully verify all the favorable sentiments that you
have published relative to Rail Roads, in the last
year or two--and perhaps induce our fellow citl-
zens to exert themselves to obtain Rail Way from
Wilmington to Elkton-and by proper degree OF
exertion obtain the requisite sum for completing it
within reasonable period Of time.

GA high pressure locomotive engine, working
with two inch cylinders, and weighing tons,
has drawn on level ~ Wagons, weighing "a tons,
at the rate of A miles an hour, and when lightly
laden, it will travel 10 miles an hour. The cost
Of one Of these Engines, is d0ol sterling"


"The introduction Of the Locomotive Engine,
has greatly changed the relative ralue Of Railways
and Canals and where communication is to be
made between places Of commercial or manufac
turing character, which maintain constant inter
course, and where rapidity Of transit becomes i'm
portant, it cannot be doubted that Raitrays nil

E1tract from Report made BY Mr. Jessop, Engi.


to the Peak Forrest Canal, at Whnley, in the


County Of Derby, Ergtand


The Railway is proposed to be constructed on
the system of levels and inclined planes. by which
steam engines may be employed, as the moving
power, to convey the wagons. The locomotive or
travelling engines, being used on the level parts,
and stationary engines at the inclined planes.
Railways so constructed, are equally adapted to
the employment OF engines horses; for on the lev
ell parts the friction Of wheels of locomotive carlia
ges against the rails. sufficient to prepel them. As
steam engines, where the trade is extensive have
many advantages over horses. conveying al much
less cost and greater expedition, it would enable pro.
pretors either to become the carriers, agree With
individuals to embark capital IN the wagons and
engines for that purpose


Jessop's Report in Strickland, p 81.


"a Railway is equally suited 70 a mountainous
or level country, and either horses or locomotive
engines may be used upon it, Though not with ad.
vantage at the same time from their difference of
veloeitv) the wagons being drawn along bv the
locomotive engine, which derives its motion from
the contact and friction Of the wheels against the
rails, the wheels being attached directly TO the
steam engine. Where Railway is level the pow.
er required to move the wagons is little more than
the friction, which is found to amount to about
200th part Of the weight to be conveyed or in
other words, power Of one pound applied in the
direction OF the motion, will draw forward oO0lb.'


- locomotive engine of ten horses po,cer, uiH
ara'c one hundred and tuenty tons, at the rate
draught horse travels; or so tons at the rate Of
miles an hour. The engine Requires the a.tcn.
dance Of on@y man and a boy, al daily expense
Of ) shlings. The GOALS consumed in 10 hours
would be iron 90 to 50 cwt. therefore the expense
altogether would be less than 50 shillinss per day,
TOR winch 50 tons may be conveyed 60 miles in ia
hours. which is less than half farthinS ton per

may be increased to sarpdss that of mail eoachgs
and that tire locomotive engine will as readily con-
vey 25 TONS ,ncluding its own weight) at the rate
OF fTetre miles an hour, as double the weioht u
twice the tine.'

they were obsated by the introduction Of inclined
places, up which the loaded wagons we're drawn

MENTOR,

TIRGINIA.-There is no State in the Union,
he real character OF which is little known, ss
tha, Of j" old Virginia The voice Of the people is
seldom ard,-neyer, indeed, in its full and effec
tive accents. A few /" lords OF the Manor" are
!, lrgitimates," and hstr voice j, heard and their
vote taken, by the people Of other States, IS the
sentiments Of the people OF Virginia There is a
race of men in that siais who resemble very much
The feude ch eitsins oi SEQ land. both IN character
and pow er. I hey were enabled TO deprive all save
freeholders Of the right OF voting, and by securing
TO themselves immense tracts OF land in the lower
and most lhickly Inhabited part OF the s,ate they
secured to then selves the political power and by
another act OF feuda intrigue ard cunning, they Sc
cured the succession TO this property and power to
their descendants by a law, which prevents the salt
Of real estate, y execution Tor debt. Thus We see in
this republican, state, " lord Of the Manor with
pompous ste. and bloatcd cheeks, srutting over
his plantation o three thousand acres, giving orders
to his overseers and laws 10 his Ssrcs, Chose, we
mean. who slaves according 10 MIR Madison's
definition Of The term) who, if his debts paid,
or if his creditors could execute his property, would
be poor and as mpotent the mcanest slave that
,ills his grounds


We have beea led 10 these remarks by the pro.
ceed,ngs Ola meeting OF the citz Of Ohio coun-
ty, in Virginia, held al Wheeling, at which, re.ou-
tions were passed approving Of .he system Of pro-
lection to domestic manufactures, adopted by con-
grcss, debating that there exists 90 constitutional
objection 10 the preservation, by congress, OF the
Cumberland Road, and concluding with the fol
loving -


Wtersns,--This meeting regards the general
government, no, as foreign, but as government
emanatng immediately from the people Of these
states and administered directly by their agents and
servants, and as government which is necessary
to the liberties, safety and happiness Of all the good
people OF these United States; and, whereas in the
opinion OF this rseetng to deny to the general gov
eminent tine power TO make roads aud canals, and
TO foster and protect domestic industry and capital
IS 10 deny 10 1t the means Of accomplishing the fal
purposes OF its establishment, and is an unwise and
improper interference with il, in the exetcsc Of an
established useful, and benefcent power--a power
that has been consecrated by the acts and usage o
all preceding admnstrations-


Resolved therefore. That this meeting view. with
deep regret the legislative adoption Of sundry reso
iutons lately moved in the general assembly Of thi.
ancient and renowned commonwealth, by that ven
cradle statesman VIM B. GILES and that, thoue


this melting does not pretend fully 10 comprehen nc
the objec, or extent Of said resolutions and how
ever harmless ihe msre legislative declaration o


distractions" may be, the truth Of which none de
ny the reverse OF which Eone affirm, yet, this NEE
ting eannot refrain from expressing its opinion tha
said resolutions are based on &c, epuve assumptio
OF Facts, and contain much tha, is Objectionable
much that is calculated 10 alarm the wlsc and re
hecling."


In these proceedings, we hear the real roice a NJ
learn the real sentiments OF the people OF Virginia
for we have little doubt tina, similar meetings u.r
held in every county Of the State, similar sentiment
would prevail, in a very large majority Of them.

Stare Trads.-On the 9Th January, II. B. NJ.
sloop-of war Redwing, arrived at Hampshire,
(Eng.) from the Western Coast of Africa, and
brought intelligence that the Slave Trade is going
on With increased activity. In short eruizc round
the Blight Of Benin only, The Redwins boarded near
y SO sad OF vessels, underth French, Spanish, Por
tuguese and Brazilian flags, all fitted for the rccep
tion Of slaves, and from the best authority it is sup
posed, that there are nearly $4,000 Of these poor
wretches ready for embarkation along the coast
and are only deferred from being instantly shipped
through the vigilance of the cruizcrs.


The English paper from which we take these par
ticulars, adds: Sc This ship presents another In.
stance Of the great number of Europeans sacrificed
in the hitherto Intellectual attempt fputing stop
70 the traffic, she having lost, during the time she
has been in commission. "a period Of less than two
years,) nine officers and nearly fifty men. OF five
officers who went ouMn her gun-room mess, and
thirteen in her midshpmen's, only one in each has
returned; the rest Except two promotedl have
either died from the effects of climate, been lost on
board detained slave vessels, or obliged to leave ths
coast from al health

A comfortable old age Is tile reward Of well
spent youth therefore. instead Of its introducing
dismal and melancholy prospect. Of decay, it should
give Us hopes OF an eternal youth IN better world

full articles.headline: FOR THE RATcHmhH.
full articles.article:
You may recollect that some time since lre1ues-
ted YOU 10 publish the information contained IN the
work published by the franklin institute, reiat',e
TO Rail Roads, as collected by the Engineer, strlcR-
land) to which you replied that IT was not IN your
power, as you had not the work to extract IRON.
have now the pleasure to put into your hands .ne
proceedings OF sundry Citizens Of Baltimore" IN
which you will find the mnrrow Of all me 1n1orma-
fion on the important subjects OF Canals, turnpike
and Rail Roads-from which beg you 10 extract
such parts as will tend to give to our fellow citi-
zens, all the requisite information to enable them TO
Judge for themselves in relation to these very I'm
portant means of communication, that promise such
great advantages not only to the Iowrs, but more
particularly to our interior Country.


1t is scarcely conceivable how the members OF
the Franklin Institute, could be the advocates OF
Canals-and should endeavor TO encourage the en-
ormous expenses that the State of Pennsylvania is
about to incur, in prosecuting her Canal system
when there is so much reason to believe that the
whole will be superseded by the Rail Road System,
within shorter period than it wall be possible to
execute their Canal-at the same time.that they
had all this information within their reach.


What is stated in the Pamphlet sent you will
fully verify all the favorable sentiments that you
have published relative to Rail Roads, in the last
year or two--and perhaps induce our fellow citl-
zens to exert themselves to obtain Rail Way from
Wilmington to Elkton-and by proper degree OF
exertion obtain the requisite sum for completing it
within reasonable period Of time.

LATEST FROM EUROPE
full articles.article:
BY the slip Hamilton, capt. Bunker. we h.,
Liverpool dates to the 12th, and London to 's ~
10th Feb. wy


Parliament met on the 9Th Feb. Variouc -,
tions had been presented before the Lord, rsM sra
Commons from owners against, and from tha ~
habtants from various counties for a repeal of j..
Corn Laws. Lord Liverpool in the upper Ham,. ms
gave notice that lie should move an address ofoss
dolence to his Majesty on his late melancholy os
and he was sure that every one of their Iordsb;n,
who heard him, would participate in that sentiment
and in the House of Commons, Mr.. Secrets.
Peel also gave notice to the same effect.


The news from Greece is very cheering: Milan
lis had destroyed the Turkish fleet near Zoa. anu
lbrahm pacha had been defeated BY Colocor0n;
and others, with the loss of 1900 killed 40 stand
of colors and 500 horses were taken. II was ,n
reported, that Redschid Pacha had been killed i
another sanguinary engagement.


In Portugal affairs assume pacific characte,
and it is probable there will be no more fighting,


The Count de Survilliers Doseph Bonapartel
has Just commissioned one of his friends in Franc.
to subscribe 1000 francs towards the monument a
be erected to 'ralna, and 1000 Francs to the luonu
ment to David


An English Jonrnal is published at Brussels, IN
der the title of .tsws from Home.


st. Petersbursh papers Of 18th Jan. state, atha
since 9th Dec. no further official accounts Of the
prosecution Of the operations Of our army in Geor
gia on the Prusslan Frontiers had been receiyed.o


Accounts from Constantinople to the 9Th Jan.
state, that no change had taken place in h.
capital. Tranquility prevailed, and trade seemed
to be resiving. Nothing new was known from
Greece. except the delivcrance Of Attisa, and
another insurrecton Of the Greek inhabitants in
the vicinity Of yolo.'


The Madrid Gazette of 25th Jan. contains
decree Of the Princess Regent Of Portugal order.
ing the Minister Of War, 20 dismiss from the Per.
tusuese. all Spaniards serving in it.

GA high pressure locomotive engine, working
with two inch cylinders, and weighing tons,
has drawn on level ~ Wagons, weighing "a tons,
at the rate of A miles an hour, and when lightly
laden, it will travel 10 miles an hour. The cost
Of one Of these Engines, is d0ol sterling"


"The introduction Of the Locomotive Engine,
has greatly changed the relative ralue Of Railways
and Canals and where communication is to be
made between places Of commercial or manufac
turing character, which maintain constant inter
course, and where rapidity Of transit becomes i'm
portant, it cannot be doubted that Raitrays nil
receius a preference IN consequence .qf this eery
pouerfut auritiory." IdeM p. 81.
E1tract from Report made BY Mr. Jessop, Engi.


to the Peak Forrest Canal, at Whnley, in the


County Of Derby, Ergtand


The Railway is proposed to be constructed on
the system of levels and inclined planes. by which
steam engines may be employed, as the moving
power, to convey the wagons. The locomotive or
travelling engines, being used on the level parts,
and stationary engines at the inclined planes.
Railways so constructed, are equally adapted to
the employment OF engines horses; for on the lev
ell parts the friction Of wheels of locomotive carlia
ges against the rails. sufficient to prepel them. As
steam engines, where the trade is extensive have
many advantages over horses. conveying al much
less cost and greater expedition, it would enable pro.
pretors either to become the carriers, agree With
individuals to embark capital IN the wagons and
engines for that purpose


Jessop's Report in Strickland, p 81.


"a Railway is equally suited 70 a mountainous
or level country, and either horses or locomotive
engines may be used upon it, Though not with ad.
vantage at the same time from their difference of
veloeitv) the wagons being drawn along bv the
locomotive engine, which derives its motion from
the contact and friction Of the wheels against the
rails, the wheels being attached directly TO the
steam engine. Where Railway is level the pow.
er required to move the wagons is little more than
the friction, which is found to amount to about
200th part Of the weight to be conveyed or in
other words, power Of one pound applied in the
direction OF the motion, will draw forward oO0lb.'


- locomotive engine of ten horses po,cer, uiH
ara'c one hundred and tuenty tons, at the rate
draught horse travels; or so tons at the rate Of
miles an hour. The engine Requires the a.tcn.
dance Of on@y man and a boy, al daily expense
Of ) shlings. The GOALS consumed in 10 hours
would be iron 90 to 50 cwt. therefore the expense
altogether would be less than 50 shillinss per day,
TOR winch 50 tons may be conveyed 60 miles in ia
hours. which is less than half farthinS ton per
mile"


Z" 1t is to be remarked that the rate of TRAVELLING
may be increased to sarpdss that of mail eoachgs
and that tire locomotive engine will as readily con-
vey 25 TONS ,ncluding its own weight) at the rate
OF fTetre miles an hour, as double the weioht u
twice the tine.'


" Where ascents and descents were unavoidable
they were obsated by the introduction Of inclined
places, up which the loaded wagons we're drawn
BY stationary engines, or the loaded wagons des
cendlng drew up the empty ones. Their present
4 degree OF perfection, has thus been gradually a..
tanned, and or years experience has fully pro.
we'd their simplicity, cheapness, and regularity,

TIRGINIA.-There is no State in the Union,
he real character OF which is little known, ss
tha, Of j" old Virginia The voice Of the people is
seldom ard,-neyer, indeed, in its full and effec
tive accents. A few /" lords OF the Manor" are
!, lrgitimates," and hstr voice j, heard and their
vote taken, by the people Of other States, IS the
sentiments Of the people OF Virginia There is a
race of men in that siais who resemble very much
The feude ch eitsins oi SEQ land. both IN character
and pow er. I hey were enabled TO deprive all save
freeholders Of the right OF voting, and by securing
TO themselves immense tracts OF land in the lower
and most lhickly Inhabited part OF the s,ate they
secured to then selves the political power and by
another act OF feuda intrigue ard cunning, they Sc
cured the succession TO this property and power to
their descendants by a law, which prevents the salt
Of real estate, y execution Tor debt. Thus We see in
this republican, state, " lord Of the Manor with
pompous ste. and bloatcd cheeks, srutting over
his plantation o three thousand acres, giving orders
to his overseers and laws 10 his Ssrcs, Chose, we
mean. who slaves according 10 MIR Madison's
definition Of The term) who, if his debts paid,
or if his creditors could execute his property, would
be poor and as mpotent the mcanest slave that
,ills his grounds


We have beea led 10 these remarks by the pro.
ceed,ngs Ola meeting OF the citz Of Ohio coun-
ty, in Virginia, held al Wheeling, at which, re.ou-
tions were passed approving Of .he system Of pro-
lection to domestic manufactures, adopted by con-
grcss, debating that there exists 90 constitutional
objection 10 the preservation, by congress, OF the
Cumberland Road, and concluding with the fol
loving -


Wtersns,--This meeting regards the general
government, no, as foreign, but as government
emanatng immediately from the people Of these
states and administered directly by their agents and
servants, and as government which is necessary
to the liberties, safety and happiness Of all the good
people OF these United States; and, whereas in the
opinion OF this rseetng to deny to the general gov
eminent tine power TO make roads aud canals, and
TO foster and protect domestic industry and capital
IS 10 deny 10 1t the means Of accomplishing the fal
purposes OF its establishment, and is an unwise and
improper interference with il, in the exetcsc Of an
established useful, and benefcent power--a power
that has been consecrated by the acts and usage o
all preceding admnstrations-


Resolved therefore. That this meeting view. with
deep regret the legislative adoption Of sundry reso
iutons lately moved in the general assembly Of thi.
ancient and renowned commonwealth, by that ven
cradle statesman VIM B. GILES and that, thoue


this melting does not pretend fully 10 comprehen nc
the objec, or extent Of said resolutions and how
ever harmless ihe msre legislative declaration o


distractions" may be, the truth Of which none de
ny the reverse OF which Eone affirm, yet, this NEE
ting eannot refrain from expressing its opinion tha
said resolutions are based on &c, epuve assumptio
OF Facts, and contain much tha, is Objectionable
much that is calculated 10 alarm the wlsc and re
hecling."


In these proceedings, we hear the real roice a NJ
learn the real sentiments OF the people OF Virginia
for we have little doubt tina, similar meetings u.r
held in every county Of the State, similar sentiment
would prevail, in a very large majority Of them.

Stare Trads.-On the 9Th January, II. B. NJ.
sloop-of war Redwing, arrived at Hampshire,
(Eng.) from the Western Coast of Africa, and
brought intelligence that the Slave Trade is going
on With increased activity. In short eruizc round
the Blight Of Benin only, The Redwins boarded near
y SO sad OF vessels, underth French, Spanish, Por
tuguese and Brazilian flags, all fitted for the rccep
tion Of slaves, and from the best authority it is sup
posed, that there are nearly $4,000 Of these poor
wretches ready for embarkation along the coast
and are only deferred from being instantly shipped
through the vigilance of the cruizcrs.


The English paper from which we take these par
ticulars, adds: Sc This ship presents another In.
stance Of the great number of Europeans sacrificed
in the hitherto Intellectual attempt fputing stop
70 the traffic, she having lost, during the time she
has been in commission. "a period Of less than two
years,) nine officers and nearly fifty men. OF five
officers who went ouMn her gun-room mess, and
thirteen in her midshpmen's, only one in each has
returned; the rest Except two promotedl have
either died from the effects of climate, been lost on
board detained slave vessels, or obliged to leave ths
coast from al health

A comfortable old age Is tile reward Of well
spent youth therefore. instead Of its introducing
dismal and melancholy prospect. Of decay, it should
give Us hopes OF an eternal youth IN better world
